title: 108_hr889
content: The Act may be cited as the "Convicted Child Sex Offender DNA Index System Support Act" and aims to eliminate the backlog of child sex offender DNA. The "Convicted Child Sex Offender DNA Index System Support Act" requires the FBI Director to develop a plan within 45 days to assist states in analyzing DNA samples from convicted child sex offenders to eliminate backlogs efficiently and enter the results into CODIS. The "Convicted Child Sex Offender DNA Index System Support Act" mandates the FBI Director to create a plan to aid states in analyzing DNA samples from convicted child sex offenders and entering the results into CODIS. The plan includes requirements for private forensic labs to perform DNA analyses with quality assurance standards and state-of-the-art testing methods. The plan mandates private forensic laboratories to meet quality standards for DNA analysis of convicted child sex offenders, with FBI Director assistance provided only to labs meeting these requirements. The plan requires private forensic labs to analyze DNA samples of convicted child sex offenders, with funding provided by the state. Access to DNA samples is restricted to law enforcement, judicial proceedings, and criminal defense purposes. The plan allows access to DNA samples for law enforcement, judicial proceedings, criminal defense purposes, and validation studies. States can use unspent funds for DNA analysis of other forensic samples. The Director of the FBI implements the plan with available appropriations. The Director of the FBI will implement the plan with States that choose to participate, using $25,000,000 in appropriations for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2005.
